head.note: The original Contents pages for Battle-Pieces, transcribed here, varies (in only minor instances of punctuation, capitalization, and the dropping of the word "Tennessee" in poem 9) from the titles appearing at the heads of eight poems. In revising his personal copy of Battle-Pieces (Copy A), and probably after his revisions in his copy of bound sheets (Copy C), Melville put check marks next to three poems in the table of contents: "The Battle for the Mississippi," "Running the Batteries," and "The Battle for the Bay."" The three checked poems themselves do not show evidence of revisions. For the table of contents in their edition of Battle-Pieces, the NN editors emended the Contents titles to match those at the heads of poems. However, MEL transcribes the Contents titles as they appear in the original. Because MEL's digital table of contents is a set of links to the poems themselves, MEL's list of contents is not an exact simulation of the first edition Contents page found here: MEL assigns numbers to each of the 72 poems, provides shortened titles in some cases, and removes the original page numbers. In MEL's TOC, the treatment of Melville's "Notes" section is also different. Originally, Melville grouped his 24 annotations together as endnotes in a "Notes" section appearing just before his "Supplement." MEL has converted Melville's notes to footnotes appearing individually at the end of each relevant poem. While MEL's interactive Table of Contents includes "Notes," that link offers page images of the Notes and references to the poems each note is attached to, where readers will find full transcriptions of the notes (as well as page images).

l.note: REVISION NARRATIVE: "The Portent" does not appear in the original Battle-Pieces table of contents. One theory is that, since the poem (unlike all other "battle-pieces") appears entirely in italic on the recto of the first page of poetry with a blank verso, Melville may have seen "The Portent" as a kind of prelude to the volume. The fact that the poem's prophetic content and focus on the pre-war events involving John Brown supports this view but does not explain why it is not listed. A more likely possibility is that Melville added "The Portent" to his collection after the table of Contents had been set in type.

div.p: [Editors' Note: In Battle-Pieces, Melville assigned letters rather than numbers as references for each of his 24 annotations and grouped them together as endnotes in a "Notes" section appearing at the end of the book, just before his "Supplement." For convenience, MEL has converted Melville's notes to footnotes and placed them at the ends of their corresponding poems. Rather than duplicating the endnotes in the link to Notes in MEL's interactive Table of Contents, we have provided here instead a list of the lettered note references, page images representing the Notes section, and the titles of the poems to which they are linked, where readers can find full transcriptions of the endnotes themselves.]
